prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dense and diffuse gas mapping of 9io9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In this science goal we will use a single tuning to observe CO(4-3) and [CI](1-0) in the target at 300mas resolution. We will get continuum for free by averaging over four basebands in line-free parts of the spectrum. The broad goals will be to (a) quantify and map the amount of dense and diffuse [total] molecular gas is in the system, and (b) use dynamical information to search for evidence of bulk motion of the gas components, such as rotation or outflows associated with the AGN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: With four spectral windows comprised of 1.875GHz-wide basebands at BB1=127.20, BB2=129.08,BB3=139.20 and BB4=141.08GHz will allow us to simultaneously map CO(4-3) and [CI] in BB2 and BB3 respectively. Aggregating the full ~7.5GHz bandwidth excluding the lines will give us 'for free' the 2mm continuum emission at the same resolution at >10-sigma. We will use a resolution of 976.563kHz (~2km/s) spectrally averaged by 8 to ~10km/s to reduce the data rate. We will further bin the spectrum to our maximum 50km/s channel width. Importantly, in the event that the lines are brighter than our prediction, then we will be able to bin to a finer velocity resolution at the same signal-to-noise (note that the CO(4-3) will certainly be brighter), and this would allow us to measure the line profile in greater detail.

Chosen resolution: our radio imaging is indicative of the distribution of flux across the source. Our aim is to spatially resolve the AGN core emission and extended emission associated with star formation in the host galaxy. Since our aim in this SG is to map a potentially faint line ([CI]) our simulations indicate that a resolution of 300mas offers the best balance between sensitivity and spatial resolution to map the source in a feasible integration time. The largest scale of the target is ~1.5-arcsec along the largest arc, and we want to be sensitive to large-scale/extended gas emission (e.g. associated with the diffuse/quiesence gas reservoir traced by [CI]) on these scales as well as compact/clumpy emission traced by dense gas.

Our sensitivity is determined by the fainter [CI] line. We estimate the total [CI] line flux in the following way:
1) We estimate CO(4-3) from the known CO(3-2) line flux (~20Jy km/s). We assume a conservative CO(3-2)/CO(4-3)=1.44 based on dense gas SLEDs in local LIRGs and ULIRGs. This gives an average flux density of ~48mJy for a 500km/s line (the width of the CO(3-2) line).
2) We aim to reach a sensitivity to measure CO(4-3)/[CI]~4.55, which is an indicator of high gas density fractions associated with active nuclei. Assuming the same line width as (1), the galaxy-integrated [CI] line flux averaged over a 500 km/s line is 12 mJy. The line will be a factor 5 brighter than this if the CO(4-3)/[CI] ratio is more like spiral discs, CO(4-3)/[CI]~1, but robustly mapping this ratio is a goal of the proposal.
3) The estimates above are for the total emission. To estimate the expected line flux at the proposed resolution of 300 mas we use our best model of the source flux from our high-resolution radio imaging, and adopt a sensitivity that will allow us to detect the line right across the Einstein ring, including the fainter features, to at least 3-sigma signficance for the [CI] line in a 50 km/s channel (CASA simulations shown in proposal). Brighter parts of the arc will be detected at higher significance, and the brighter CO(4-3) line will be detected at higher significance still. The bandwidth is chosen so that we can measure line profiles across the source down to widths of ~150 km/s, essential for understanding the gas dynamics. The velocity-integrated maps will of course be at >5-sigma significance across the target.
The model indicates that a sensitivity of ~250uJy in a 50 km/s channel at 139.2GHz is required to detect the minimum line flux of ~750uJy (over a 500 km/s line) at >3-sigma per beam and 50 km/s spectral resolution element. We stress that these sensitivity estimates are for the most conservative case of [CI], allowing very sensitive constraints of CO(4-3)/[CI].

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 9 continuum mapping of 9io9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust mapping of the gravitational arc in Band 9 to 150mas resolution. [NII]122 will be included in the band.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We choose a standard set-up for single continuum observations with dual polarization. Note that [NII]122um is expected in the band at 692.2GHz, which we will search for emission from (see non-standard continuum frequency justification).

The angular scale 150mas is chosen to allow for scheduling of the target during nighttime observations in configuration C36.5, which, given the configuration schedule is the only likely way the target could be observed at this high frequency (as recommended by the proposal guide). The source is bright enough to warrant this resolution and we have simulated the observations accordingly. The high resolution will allow us to map the dust emission on small spatial scales and refine our lensing model even further. We will be able to uv-taper the observations for more direct comparison to our 300mas radio data. Although pushing to even higher resolution might be possible, we have no source model to predict the emission on scales much smaller than this. The proposed resolution is adequate for our science goals, and note that the lensing effect means that we are actually probing scales of ~20mas in the source plane.
We need to be sensitive to emission on scales of ~1.5-arcsec, which is approximately the length of the long radio arc in our existing imaging. It is possible that the gas and dust components could be distributed on this scale.

We have an accurate measure of the total flux right across the mm-submm SED from single dish observations. The single dish data are well-fit by a modified blackbody allowing us to estimate the total flux in Band 9. We will resolve the emission, and so our sensitivity estimate is based on our best sky model of the source emission which comes from our resolved eMERLIN and JLVA radio observations at the same proposed resolution. We have used CASA to simulate the observations (results in proposal) to verify our approach. We base the rms sensitivity on the level required to detect the continuum emission from the faintest part of the arc at a level of 10-sigma. We require this high significance detection to perform a very good fit of the thermal dust SED across the arc to constrain the dust temperature, and in order to be sensitive to even fainter structures that our radio imaging might not be accurately modelling (part of the science goal is to see how the mm emission compares to the radio).
From our model described abobe, in Band 9 the continuum emission is expected to be ~4mJy at 692GHz for radio-faint parts of the arc, so we aim for a sensitivity of 0.4mJy over 7.5GHz bandwidth.

The line [NII]122um is expected in Band 9 at 692.2GHz, and therefore we tune to 689.25GHz to place [NII]122um in the centre of baseband 4. This non-standard tuning has been taken into account in the sensitivity estimate.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 8 continuum mapping of 9io9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust mapping of the gravitational arc in Band 8 to 150mas resolution. [NII]205 will be included in the band.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We choose a standard set-up for single continuum observations with dual polarization. Note that [NII]205um is expected in the banda at 411.2GHz, which we will search for emission from (see non-standard continuum frequency justification).

The angular scale 150mas is chosen to allow for scheduling of the target during nighttime observations in configuration C36.5, which, given the configuration schedule is the only likely way the target could be observed at this high frequency (as recommended by the proposal guide). The source is bright enough to warrant this resolution and we have simulated the observations accordingly. The high resolution will allow us to map the dust emission on small spatial scales and refine our lensing model even further. We will be able to uv-taper the observations for more direct comparison to our 300mas radio data. Although pushing to even higher resolution might be possible, we have no source model to predict the emission on scales much smaller than this. The proposed resolution is adequate for our science goals, and note that the lensing effect means that we are actually probing scales of ~20mas in the source plane.
We need to be sensitive to emission on scales of ~1.5-arcsec, which is approximately the length of the long radio arc in our existing imaging. It is possible that the gas and dust components could be distributed on this scale.

We have an accurate measure of the total flux right across the mm-submm SED from single dish observations. The single dish data are well-fit by a modified blackbody allowing us to estimate the total flux in Band 8. We will resolve the emission, and so our sensitivity estimate is based on our best sky model of the source emission which comes from our resolved eMERLIN and JLVA radio observations at the same proposed resolution. We have used CASA to simulate the observations (results in proposal) to verify our approach. We base the rms sensitivity on the level required to detect the continuum emission from the faintest part of the arc at a level of 10-sigma. We require this high significance detection to perform a very good fit of the thermal dust SED across the arc to constrain the dust temperature, and in order to be sensitive to even fainter structures that our radio imaging might not be accurately modelling (part of the science goal is to see how the mm emission compares to the radio).
From our model described abobe, in Band 8 the continuum emission is expected to be ~1mJy at 411GHz for radio-faint parts of the arc, so we aim for a sensitivity of 0.1mJy over 7.5GHz bandwidth.

The line [NII]205um is expected in Band 8 at 411.2GHz, and therefore we tune to 404.5GHz to place [NII] in the centre of baseband 4. This non-standard tuning has been taken into account in the sensitivity estimate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have identified a gravitationally lensed radio-loud AGN at z=2.6 with exceptionally bright sub-mm flux (~1Jy at peak). We will use ALMA to perform a detailed study of gas and dust in this system, which is the progenitor of a massive galaxy today, but seen less than 3Gyr after the Big Bang and caught in a phase where radio-mode feedback could be in action. We will study the astrophysics of the dense/cold ISM in this system, resolving star formation in the host from the AGN on physical scales of 175-350pc. We will: (a) map CO(4-3) and [CI](1-0) to trace the mass and dynamics of the dense and diffuse molecular reservoirs. We will use this diagnostic to reveal variations in the gas mass density fraction which is sensitive to the ISM turbulent velocity structure; and (b) obtain matched-resolution continuum maps in Band 4+8+9 to construct a resolved map of the thermal dust emission. We will use this to quantify the relative contribution of the AGN and starburst to the bolometric luminosity and map the radio-to-IR ratio, and map temperature variations in the average dust temperature to investigate the potential role and region of influence of AGN heating.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
